awd_titl_txt: ISS: GOALI: Nonequilibrium Processing of Particle Suspensions with Thermal and Electrical Field Gradients
awd_abstract_narration:
Colloidal particles are particles with diameters between approximately 1 nanometer and 1 micron.  They can be considered as blocks for building materials, like atoms for forming molecules and crystals.  In colloidal crystals, the particles are organized in periodic structures with ordering on a range of length scales from nanometers to millimeters or larger.   Research on colloidal crystals is motivated by several factors.  They can be used to answer fundamental questions related to the assembly of materials, and they have many potential applications in electronics, photonics, and life sciences.  However, the rich variety of colloidal crystal structures observed on earth are influenced by the effects of gravity, which leads to particles settling and may lead to motion of the surrounding fluid.  In this study, a team of researchers will study colloidal crystal formation in both normal gravity in Earth-based experiments and in microgravity on the International Space Station (ISS).  These experiments will reveal the important roles that gravity and external forces play on particle assembly.  Ultimately, the researchers will obtain a better understanding of how to manipulate external forces to create colloidal crystals for high resolution 3D printing on Earth and in space.
 
Mechanisms for formation of metastable and glassy phases in particle suspensions will be studied in the ISS and for comparison on Earth. Colloidal particle suspensions are the logical candidates to take advantage of long duration microgravity because (i) they are important for a wide range of terrestrial and space applications, (ii) they share the common feature of coupling between macroscopic particle transport and structure transformations at a particle level and (iii) an adequate explanation for basic features of structure formation in suspensions observed in Earth experiments has not been made to date. Although the time and equipment available for both ground and microgravity experiments is limited, the team of researchers plans to have an impact in many of these areas due to the novel use of field gradients to manipulate the particle density, which is the control parameter for suspensions. Thus, instead of using many different samples to access the interesting range of particle densities, a single sample will be arranged in a field gradient in the sample cell to cover this range. As the particle density is directly measured by microscopy in suspension experiments, a priori knowledge of the gradient profile is not required. The experiments involve setting up the field gradients and observing the resulting structures and then locally mixing a region of known density to watch it glassify or crystallize. Some knowledge of the suspension rheology will come from observations of mixing processes, but quantitative data will come from microrheology measurements through tracking particle thermal motion. The use of colloidal suspensions with real space-time microscopic observations in these studies makes them particularly attractive for teaching students at all levels. We have and will continue to participate in education programs that use space themes to improve interest and skills in STEM, to work with educational professionals to translate the project work to lesson plans for the benefit of students in middle and high school grades and to engage high school and undergraduate students in laboratory work as well as to train and educate undergraduate and graduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

The self-assembly of colloidal materials is the spontaneous organization of microscopic particles into ordered structures, ideally with targeted properties. The implemetation of this strategy allows the colloidal particles to function as building blocks of new materials in myriad technologies including materials engineering, electronics, optics, life science, chemical and pharmaceutical industries. Ensembles of 'hard' colloidal particles, the focus of this investigation, also serve as the basic model in the statistical physics of fluids and solids. Defined as impenetrable particles that cannot overlap in space, they mimic the extremely strong repulsion that atoms and molecules experience at very close distances and provide a theoretical model for the structure and dynamics of phase transitions in simple liquids.

Numerous computer simulations reported in the literature have predicted rich phase diagrams of colloidal systems. However, Earth-based experiments were found to be of limited use to validate these results because of gravitational effects, such as sedimentation, convection and jamming of particles. These microgravity experiments were designed to investigate the nature of phase transitions in colloids at a particle level in the absence of gravity.

Six samples comprised of fluorescent ellipsoidal particles were delivered to the ISS in March 2020 on SpaceX-20. Colloidal structures formed in microgravity were studied during Sept-Oct 2020 and Jan-Feb 2021. The micrometer-sized particles in these experiments are huge in comparison to molecules, which are too small to be seen with an optical microscope. The motion of individual particles could therefore be recorded using a 100x oil immersion objective on a confocal microscope remotely operated in the ISS (Figure 1). This arrangement allowed the measurement of individual particle displacements in the course of phase transitions in three-dimensional structures.

Experiments in long-duration microgravity in the ISS confirmed theoretical predictions for equilibrium phase diagrams. For the first time, our results demonstrated that inconsistency between results of computer simulations and observations in terrestrial experiments is caused by gravitational effects. This outcome opens an avenue for the use of computer simulations for modeling materials processing in microgravity. Understanding the role of gravity effects brought by this work should help test predictions of current theories for colloidal dispersions and develop novel technologies that can be applied to combine materials with different densities in manufacturing. The expected outcome would have the potential to make novel colloidal materials in a low-Earth orbit and return them to Earth for various applications.

Broader impact

One exciting aspect of the experiments aboard the ISS is the realization that in microgravity we can build large three-dimensional (3D) colloidal photonic crystals that would survive re-entry to Earth's atmosphere. In this experiment, a photonic crystal is an ordered structure in which the refractive index changes periodically with lattice parameters comparable to the wavelength of infrared (IR) light (0.8 to 1,000 micrometers). This feature influences propagation of IR photons by the same way as the atomic crystal, in which the refractive index repeats periodically on the angstrom scale in a three-dimensional lattice, gives rise to X-ray diffraction.

Photonic crystals can be engineered to control and manipulate the flow of IR light. The mid-IR spectral region of 2–20 micrometers contains characteristic vibrational transitions of many important molecules, as well as two atmospheric transmission windows. Due to these unique properties, photonic materials operating at IR wavelengths are crucial for applications in remote sensing, fiber-optic communication, composition analysis, biomedical diagnostics, optical computing, security and defense.

An attractive feature of colloidal suspensions is the ability to spontaneously form 3D crystals with lattice parameters of the order of 1 micrometer. However, fabrication of large-scale 3D colloidal materials on Earth remains a challenge as the particle assembly is strongly influenced by undesirable gravity effects. A stringent requirement for precise matching of the particle and host fluid densities to avoid undesirable gravity influence severely limits the possibilities for building colloidal crystals on Earth. As the ISS experiments demonstrated, long-duration microgravity in a low-Earth orbit (LEO) adds literally another dimension to the challenge of fabricating 3D colloidal materials and devices.

Our experiments revealed that changing the particle sizes, shapes and properties would make it possible to vary the wavelength of light we wish to control with a colloidal crystal fabricated in microgravity. The research team submitted a patent application for fabrication of large-scale colloidal photonic materials in low Earth orbit and returning them to Earth. This invention is based on the outcome of the ISS experiments supported by NSF CBET 1832260 and 1832291 grants to NJIT and NYU and several related NASA contracts.
